channel.title: WHATWG DOM Workstream-relevant MDN issues
channel.description: Issue filed on MDN Web Docs related to pages attached to technologies developed by WHATWG DOM Workstream

item.title: [dom] MutationObserver no "Baseline Widely available" badge
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Header

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

No "Baseline Widely available" badge

What did you expect to see?

badge "Baseline Widely available"

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

item.title: [html, dom, uievents] Event pages: claim (or imply) that onXYZ and addEventListener are equivalent but they are not
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/load_event

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

No response

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

From #35008: on pages like "Window: load event", we say "The same, but using the onload event handler property:", but these two are not equivalent in all cases. Even when the page doesn't have this example, the syntax section, which says "Use the event name in methods like addEventListener(), or set an event handler property." implies that this is the case.

What did you expect to see?

More nuance by linking to https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/JavaScript/Building_blocks/Events#other_event_listener_mechanisms and more explanation on their differences, to every event page.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

Maybe we should do other changes to the event pages tooâ€”the event pages generally don't seem very informative and it's not easy to find a single, definitive guide to events in the web API references, discussing things like event IDL attributes, how the return value of onXYZ works, etc. If there does exist such a guide it should be linked everywhere. See also: #34684

item.title: [dom] Element.shadowRoot should note browser shadow roots aren't accessible
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/ShadowRoot

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Either the first, untitled section, or the "Value" section

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The Element.shadowRoot article might be more helpful if it explicitly notes that shadowRoot can't be used to access a shadow root added by a browser, like Chrome's shadow root on <video>.

What did you expect to see?

For example:

Element.shadowRoot cannot be used to access a shadow root added by a browser. For example, Google Chrome adds a shadow root on <video>, but it cannot be accessed with Element.shadowRoot.

Language like "user-agent", "native", or "shadow DOM" might also be appropriate, I'm not sure.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

I haven't found specific documentation that states the above, but it matches my experience, and this stack overflow answer makes an argument that is persuasive to me.

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

MDN metadata

Page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/shadowroot
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/ShadowRoot
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/shadowroot/index.md
  • Last commit: 4558d20
  • Document last modified: 2024-06-19T05:39:51.000Z

item.title: [dom] Various Node subclass replaceWith methods should link to each other
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/replaceWith

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

See also

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

the pages aren't very well interlinked

What did you expect to see?

the pages be interlinked

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

Element.replaceWith does not mention CharacterData.replaceWith or DocumentType.replaceWith
DocumentType.replaceWith does not mention CharacterData.replaceWith
CharacterData.replaceWith does not mention Element.replaceWith or DocumentType.replaceWith

Do you have anything more you want to share?

the Node.replaceChild docs mention/suggest using Element.replaceWith() instead, but don't mentioned CharacterData.replaceWith or DocumentType.replaceWith, and b/c those pages don't link to each other either, this led to me concluding that replaceWith was not usable in all practical situations until i did more research, when in fact it is, and replaceWith is very awesome and cool

item.title: [dom] Chrome has XMLNS as default namespace
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Node/isDefaultNamespace

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Example

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The first js comment is correct for the current version of Firefox, but incorrect for Chrome Version 117.0.5938.149:

  result[0].value = aHtmlElt.isDefaultNamespace(""); // true
  result[1].value = aHtmlElt.isDefaultNamespace("http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"); // false
  result[2].value = aSvgElt.isDefaultNamespace(""); // false
  result[3].value = aSvgElt.isDefaultNamespace("http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"); // true

In current Chrome, the default namespace is the XMLNS namespace.

This might also necessitate changing the following note at the top of the page:

Note: The default namespace of an HTML element is always "". For a SVG element, it is set by the xmlns attribute.

because apparently the default namespace of an HTML element is not always "" in Chrome.

What did you expect to see?

I expected to see some information on the different behaviour of Chrome and Firefox.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

To verify this yourself please try running https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/play?id=eh%2B17UrEbnCYBf5KFLCPxU%2BpuZ%2BpjterwKRsJ0busUMroHAbbOFG1hVEO7aszxufknzVzRtSt4F7gFBx in Chrome Version 117.0.5938.149

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

MDN metadata

Page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/node/isdefaultnamespace
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Node/isDefaultNamespace
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/node/isdefaultnamespace/index.md
  • Last commit: 1c6511c
  • Document last modified: 2023-09-11T08:48:36.000Z

item.title: [html, dom, cssom-view-1, uievents, pointerlock-2, selection-api, page-visibility-2] Keydown, keyup, keypress pages should mention they work on document, body, etc
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/keydown_event

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

main section(?)

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The keydown, keyup, and keypress pages don't explicitly mention that keyboard events are also "generated"/can be installed on by window, document, <html> and <body>. The keydown page implies that is the case via the sentence
If not caught, they bubble up the DOM tree until they reach Document, but it would be better to be explicit, and the the keyup page currently lacks this sentence. (The keypress article currently fails to also mention the preceding sentence: Keyboard events are only generated by <input>, <textarea>, <summary> and anything with the contentEditable or tabindex attribute)

What did you expect to see?

The keydown, keyup, and keypress pages should explicitly mention that keyboard events are "generated"/installable on window, document, <html> and <body>

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

I would've edited the pages myself but I wasn't sure how to (re)write them to incorporate the info. (also, editing via github web is annoying)

Also, I suppose this should be a separate issue, but the pages also fail to mention that elements with implicit tabindexs (such as <a>) also generate keyboard events.

MDN metadata

Page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/element/keydown_event
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/keydown_event
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/element/keydown_event/index.md
  • Last commit: bbf7f25
  • Document last modified: 2023-04-07T05:55:26.000Z

item.title: [dom, cssom-view-1, uievents, pointerlock-2, pointerevents3, fullscreen, DOM-Parsing] MouseDown & MouseUp event articles should compare them to PointerDown & PointerUp
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/mouseup_event

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Introduction, for Mouse Up, Pointer Up, MouseDown and PointerDown

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

"The mouseup event is fired at an Element when a button on a pointing device (such as a mouse or trackpad) is released while the pointer is located inside it."

The way I interpret this is, MouseUp happens when ANY of the buttons on the mouse is released. So , if user is holding down Left and Right buttons, releases the Left, then a mouseUp happens, even though the Right button is still down.

compare with the intro for PointerUp:
"The pointerup event is fired when a pointer is no longer active."

The way I interpret this is, PointerUp only happens when the last of all the buttons is released, so zero buttons are still pressed. So , if user is holding down Left and Right buttons, releases the Left, then no PointerUp happens, because the Right button is still down. Only when hte Right button is finally released, does the PointerUP event happen.

What did you expect to see?

Is what I just wrote right? Kindof vaguely implied by comparing the PointerUp and MouseUp articles. The MouseDown article is similllarly vague, although the POinterDown article nails down the issue better:

"The pointerdown event is fired when a pointer becomes active. For mouse, it is fired when the device transitions from no buttons pressed to at least one button pressed. For touch, ...."

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

https://w3c.github.io/pointerevents/#dfn-chorded-buttons

Pointer Events do not fire overlapping pointerdown and pointerup events for chorded button presses (depressing an additional button while another button on the pointer device is already depressed).

Do you have anything more you want to share?

Most seriously, neither of the Mouse articles mention the Pointer events, and neither of the Pointer articles mention the Mouse events. These are important distinctions, and part of the reason why the Pointer events were invented.

Another example: the user can press the Left button down (MouseDown and PointerDown), then press and release the Right button, and no PointerDown or Up events will result, although MouseDown and Up events will happen. And, the user can then hold down both, and then release and press the Left button: Mouse Up and Down events will happen, but still no Pointer Up/Down events, because the whole time, at least one button remains pressed.

So, this relationship should be explained in one or another article(s). You can probably just expand the PointerDown article with such an explanation, and make sure the other three briefly describe it, and point to the PointerDown article for details.

MDN metadata

Page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/element/mouseup_event
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/mouseup_event
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/element/mouseup_event/index.md
  • Last commit: 757f33e
  • Document last modified: 2023-06-26T04:47:03.000Z

item.title: [dom] Event.preventDefault: Inaccessible example
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Event/preventDefault

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

The example that displays an error message for 2 seconds only

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The error message appears for 2 seconds and then it disappears.

The error message is inaccessible and sets the wrong method to write code.

It assumes the user has fully functional eyes.

It assumes that the user is sharp and can read the error message as fast as possible.

What did you expect to see?

The error message has to have the right semantics and does not disappear within 2 seconds.

I expect to see an accessible error message another example is used to demonstrate the event.preventDefault function (which on its own is anti-accessibility feature to begin with).

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

MDN metadata

Page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/event/preventdefault
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Event/preventDefault
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/event/preventdefault/index.md
  • Last commit: 3395959
  • Document last modified: 2023-04-07T05:59:30.000Z

item.title: [service-workers-1, dom, cssom-view-1, notifications, pointerevents3] Page titles should reflect usage: crypto.getRandomValues instead of Crypto: getRandomValues()
item.content:encoded:
A big step forward was made in #8351, but I'd like to propose this rule to page naming:

  1. If the item is available on the global, use the name. Eg:
    • ServiceWorkerGlobalScope.skipWaiting becomes skipWaiting.
  2. If the item is typically reached via properties reachable from the global, use that property chain, omitting the global.
    • Document.querySelector becomes document.querySelector.
    • CacheStorage.match becomes caches.match.
  3. If the item is an instance method/property, use the constructor name with the first set of caps lower-cased + the property name.
    • Element.getBoundingClientRect becomes element.getBoundingClientRect.
    • HTMLElement.offsetHeight becomes htmlElement.offsetHeight.
  4. If the item is a static method/property, use the constructor name + the property name.
    • Notification.requestPermission remains Notification.requestPermission.
  5. Otherwise, just use the name.
    • PointerEvent remains PointerEvent

item.title: [html, dom, WebIDL-1, cssom-view-1, FileAPI, uievents, pointerlock-2] Remove alert() from live samples
item.content:encoded:
window.alert() doesn't work cross-origin in Chrome any more, meaning that any of our live samples that rely on alert() are now broken.

See also #7553.

This is (I think) all the live samples in Web/API that use alert() in a live sample (list now maintained by @Josh-Cena):

  • Games/Tutorials/2D_Breakout_game_pure_JavaScript/Build_the_brick_field
  • Games/Tutorials/2D_Breakout_game_pure_JavaScript/Collision_detection
  • Games/Tutorials/2D_Breakout_game_pure_JavaScript/Finishing_up
  • Games/Tutorials/2D_Breakout_game_pure_JavaScript/Game_over
  • Games/Tutorials/2D_Breakout_game_pure_JavaScript/Mouse_controls
  • Games/Tutorials/2D_Breakout_game_pure_JavaScript/Track_the_score_and_win
  • Learn/JavaScript/First_steps/Variables #34487
  • MDN/Writing_guidelines/Page_structures/Live_samples #34479
  • Web/API/Attr/localName
  • Web/API/Canvas_API/Tutorial/Applying_styles_and_colors #34629
  • Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/addHitRegion
  • Web/API/Document/queryCommandState
  • Web/API/DOMException/DOMException
  • Web/API/Element/scrollWidth #34733
  • Web/API/EventTarget/addEventListener
  • Web/API/File/name
  • Web/API/HTMLInputElement/showPicker
  • Web/API/KeyboardEvent/metaKey
  • Web/API/MouseEvent
  • Web/API/Notifications_API/Using_the_Notifications_API #34734
  • Web/API/WebGL_API/By_example/Simple_color_animation
  • Web/API/WebGL_API/By_example/Clearing_by_clicking
  • Web/API/Window/find
  • Web/API/WindowOrWorkerGlobalScope/setTimeout #7560

(I might have missed some).

In addition, the following ones use prompt() and are also broken:

  • Learn/JavaScript/First_steps/Strings
  • Learn/JavaScript/First_steps/What_is_JavaScript
  • Web/API/HTMLTextAreaElement

We should replace all of these with some alternative. A common alternative is to write the output into an element in the example's document.
